reviews.review_msg: Fact is, if you show that you care about the material, do the readings and contribute in class, you're going to do very well. But if you're not willing to to put in the effort/have an open mind to racial and LGBTQ2IA+ issues, don't even bother. Elise can be unorganized and is unorthodox in teaching, but she cares and works with you no matter what.
Best professor ever! He is very considerate. He a G of prof!!!

Very high % of grade is on participation, not just attendance. 3 Readings per week, ~90 pages average. Slow but easy grader. Very approachable, nice, and inclusive (so don't worry about participating). Even when you give really bad answers, he doesn't react negatively or denies your opinion. Only gripe is that he's a slow grader.

I credit Professor May for being one of the most approachable and helpful teachers at SFU. There are a lot of readings to do to be prepared for his classes, but if you do, you will do well. I took this class for my indigenous requirement as a teacher, so I recommend it to anybody planning to do PDP. He grades his assignments tough, but fair.
Great Professor. His seminars were very informative and engaging. Very helpful about essays and sources and stuff like that. Definitely would recommend!

Dr. Seager delivers a course rich in textual breadth, film, art gallery and museum visits, student presentations and a guest speaker - great connectors for the themes of BC history to current issues.  He is patient, considerate and encouraging;  attention to and note of his in-class comments are boosters for the final exam.   A gem of a course.

I can't comment much on his lecturing since he didn't do any in hist 436, but he was very kind and made students feel at ease when presenting. During the break he'd sometimes come back with cups of water or snacks to share with students. First few classes were boring without any presentations, but after that they were fine.
Quite easy, just do the readings and assignments, and you will be laughing.  Nothing stressful, easy going prof - no pressure in seminars.  Very passionate about course knowledge.

I am surprised by the reviews on this site.  He does expect a lot from his students, but I found that if you put in the effort, it was very well received.  I totally agreed with the participation mark he assigned because it forces you to keep up with the work.  I really enjoyed his class.

He expects a lot and lets you know right from the beginning but is very approachable and helpful if you go and speak to him.  If you're prepared to put the effort in you'll get a lot out of his class.

A young prof, so I think he is still figuring things out but he is very energetic and enthusiastic about British Columbia history. Open to multiple viewpoints and likes to listen to people's opinions and experiences. Not a topic I would usually be interested in but I enjoyed studying it with him. Not a tough marker.

Stuart is an amazing orator, but his teaching style is definitely not for everyone. If you are a visual learner and have difficulty following classes that are lecture heavy, you will find his classes difficult. That being said, if you are a good note-taker, you participate, and go to see him outside of class, you will do well and get good grades.

Grade scheme is quite arbitrary, little feedback is given on projects or papers, even if grade is mediocre. Class participation was mandatory including attendance to lecture, but lecture material often was not related or important to course assignments.

Jennifer is one of my favourite profs ever. She is so caring and understanding and really levels the playing field between prof and student so you don't feel so much pressure or anxiety participating in discussions. She is very knowledgeable and poses very interesting and thought provoking discussion prompts that translate into an engaging time!

The most democratic professor alive, Mark is by far the best in the school. He listens! And he is fair! And he understands students priorities. Take every course he teaches because you will learn a heck of a lot. And he plays the banjo.
